Sullivan: Pitino passion evident from win No. 1

Sullivan: Pitino passion evident from win No. 1

Pitino wins number game 700 in his coaching career. Scott Utterback/The Courier-Journal

Tim Sullivan, tsullivan@courier-journal.com 11:01 p.m. EST November 26, 2014

U of L head coach Rick Pitino, left, received a fist bump from athletic director Tom Jurich after Pitino earned his 700th career victory against Cleveland State and was honored at the conclusion of the game at the KFC Yum! Center.(Photo: Sam Upshaw Jr./The Courier-Journal)

1 CONNECT 10 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

Rick Pitino prowls the sideline with the nurturing demeanor of a drill sergeant. Stamping his feet, clenching his fists, clutching his head, straining his vocal cords, the University of Louisville's Hall of Fame basketball coach carries himself like a man courting a coronary.

He is seldom still. He is often shouting. He treats nearly every possession like a break-in at the mint, with a sense of singular urgency, unrelated to the score. Pitino says he is able to enjoy the game when it is well-played, but he typically presents the portrait of an aggrieved perfectionist, a guy who keeps winning even as he looks as if he's about to lose it.

Cause and effect? That's too simplistic. Great coaches project a wide range of personalities, from mellow to maniacal, sometimes by the same guy on the same night. Still, on the occasion of Pitino's 700th victory as a college coach Wednesday's 45-33 conquest of Cleveland State his dogged attention to detail was hard to miss and easy to hear.

RELATED: Cards find Pitino's 700th is a struggle, 45-33

RELATED: Game Rewind | U of L holds off Cleveland State

For a man who has won two NCAA titles and earned many millions of dollars, the 62-year-old grandfather has lost none of his edge and remains, in his son Richard's estimate, the world's "worst loser."

"It's been a great run," Pitino said. "The thing I'm proudest of is I've been able to keep passion for the game and love for the game. I think I love the game more than I did in my 20s. . .I hope I can go for a long time."

No. 700 was a grind. Two nights after Louisville bludgeoned Savannah State, 87-26, the Cardinals struggled to distance themselves from a Cleveland State team that had lost to Savannah State only last Saturday. The Cardinals missed 17 of their 20 shots from three-point range, 12 of their 26 free throws and had only five players produce points. It was still a five-point game with less than six minutes to play.

Yet as the game grew tighter, and later, Pitino appeared to loosen up. He sat more. He screamed less. The death stares he delivered during first-half timeouts were replaced by reassuring nods and more measured tones. He had been to this point too many times in too many places to push his players into critical mistakes of anxiety. Louisville would win ugly, but it would win.

An attentive coach learns a few things along the way, including when to push his players and when to back off the throttle. For a coach whose way has been as long as Rick Pitino's, strategic and stylistic moves can be repeated literally thousands of times.

Cards pull away late

Pitino won his first game at 23 years old, as an interim coach at the University of Hawaii, on Feb. 28, 1976, against Portland, 82-58.

"We thought we've got them in a good situation," said Jack Avina, then Portland's coach. "He'd just taken over the team. (But) He took over and he didn't seem to have any problems getting them to do what he wanted to do."

Avina is 85, and some of the specifics have faded from his memory, but as a general rule he thought of Hawaii as a road trip mainland teams took expecting to get homered.

"You would just get jobbed," Avina said. "The last time we played them, they called me up and they needed a game. Sure enough, they had two Hawaiian officials and they beat us. It was worth the loss because we spent five days in Hawaii."

The record shows that Avina was the losing coach in both of Pitino's first two victories, and that he accumulated three technical fouls in the process.

Asked for his own recollection, Pitino remembered the perils of early responsibility.

"I had six guys," he said. "I'm 23. I gave them a curfew. They were all 24. I had to knock on the rooms and not one guy was in. I was worried about my future."

Tim Sullivan can be reached at (502) 582-4650, by email at tsullivan@courier-journal.com, and on Twitter @TimSullivan714
